abstracts.cdata!:
The Cinchona project in Rwanda was
            designed to expand and reinforce the Cinchona Division of
            OCIR-Cafe, the implementing agency, to accelerate the
            cinchona smallholder planting program in the prefectures of
            Cyangugu, Gikongoro and Kibuye, through: (i) increasing the
            supply of planting material; (ii) strengthening the
            extension services to smallholders; and (iii) improving both
            internal and external marketing arrangements for cinchona
            bark. The objective was to plant 900 ha of cinchona trees.
            The project was implemented smoothly, but its success was
            seriously undermined by sharp decreases in world cinchona
            prices over the implementation period. An ounce of Quinine
            Sulphate was selling at US$6.50 during project preparation
            but, by 1977 the price had fallen to US$4.50 per ounce and
            kept falling thereafter to US$2.30 per ounce. The decline of
            quinine sulphate prices has had a major impact on the rates
            of return and there are major risks of further deterioration
            in world prices of quinine sulphate, which, again, might
            disrupt the purchase of cinchona bark. Farmers may also be
            unwilling to plant cinchona seedlings again once they have
            uprooted their trees and harvested their crop.

The Cinchona project in Rwanda was
            designed to expand and reinforce the Cinchona Division of
            OCIR-Cafe, the implementing agency, to accelerate the

            Cyangugu, Gikongoro and Kibuye, through: (i) increasing the

docna.cdata!:
Rwanda - Cinchona Project : Credit 0656 -
            Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Rwanda - Cinchona Project :
            Credit 0656 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would assist smallholders in
            improving and developing the production of cinchona.
            Specifically, it would provide: (a) farm inputs, extension
            and marketing services to facilitate smallholder cinchona
            production; (b) additional staff for OCIR and staff
            training; and (c) consultants' services to assist in
            the execution of the project and to advise on agricultural
            development in general.
